thread.title: NYSE Trading Malfunction 'Not A Cyber Breach'
thread.title_full: NYSE Trading Malfunction 'Not A Cyber Breach'

title: NYSE Trading Malfunction 'Not A Cyber Breach'
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Wed, Jul 8, 2015, 22:29 BST - UK Markets closed NYSE Trading Malfunction 'Not A Cyber Breach' By (c) Sky News 2015 | Sky News â€“ 3 minutes 57 seconds ago View Photo 

The glitch that stopped trading on the New York Stock Exchange for nearly four hours was not caused by hackers, say officials. 
The disruption on the world's largest equity market began at about 11.30am local time and trading did not begin again until 3.10pm. 
The NYSE said in tweets: "The issue we are experiencing is an internal technical issue and is not the result of a cyber breach. 
"We chose to suspend trading on NYSE to avoid problems arising from our technical issue. 
"NYSE-listed securities continue to trade unaffected on other market centers." 
The exchange, which has a market capitalisation of about $20trn, cancelled all open orders during the computer malfunction. 
Homeland Security Secretary Jeh Johnson said the NYSE halt and a glitch that temporarily grounded all United Airlines flights earlier in the day were apparently not related to "nefarious" activity. 
FBI Director James Comey told the Senate Intelligence committee: "We do not see any indication of a cyber breach or a cyber attack." 
Investors were still able to buy and sell stocks because there was no interruption at the dozens of other US stock exchanges, including the Nasdaq. 
Such halts are rare but not unheard of - two years ago the Nasdaq suspended trading for three hours because of a broken price feed. 
NYSE President Tom Farley told CNBC on Wednesday: "It's not a good day. I don't feel good for our customers who are having to deal with the fallout." 
The White House said earlier it was monitoring the situation, along with the Treasury Department. 
Josh Earnest, White House press secretary, said: "There is no indication that there are malicious actors involved." 
The Securities and Exchange Commission, the US financial markets regulator, was also keeping an eye on the NYSE halt. 
The Wall Street Journal's website also suffered "technical difficulties". 
But the FBI said that issue was probably caused by a surge in readers looking for information about the NYSE breakdown.
